Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Pratoman I'm not a doctor and so I hesitate to give advice. As I'm sure you know, any grade 5 cells, are nasty. But it looks like you got a negative margin at the site of the grade 5, so it could be all out. You might need SRT. BUT THE LONGER YOU WAIT THE LESS CHANCE OF LASTING INCONTINENCE, and ED. So give yourself as much time To heal as possible. Any improvement of incontinence and erectile function, is frozen once you start radiation. For me, I'd want to see what my post op PSA is and if it's undetectable then I'd not be inclined to rush into salvage radiation. Yes... This ^^^. It's basically what I followed. They tested me closely every month after the initial three months. After nine months, I popped up detectable. So SRT i went. All good now. Get advice from your RO sooner than later. But do heal first.

Posts.Content: Just came back from MDA today and can possibly answer this. Gleason 7's have a greater chance of recurrence. The pathology result here indicates positive margins. There is a school of thought to be proactive and preemptive, rather than wait for the PSA to begin rising. It was reported to me that it significantly increases the chances of NO RECURRENCE. Not sure why they would be already prescribing HT in this case; unless they were certain they had left some in during the surgery. In my case, my margins tested negative. I tested zero again today for now my second time, 3 months post op. MDA has a fancy $4,000 test (can't remember the name right now; but it uses the pathology of the prostate to perform their predictive analysis) which gives a better indication of possible recurrence than the Memorial Sloan Kettering tables. They tell me it's a better predictor than waiting for the PSA to rise above 0.1 . Personally, I am still waiting, even if their test shows I need Adjuvant Treatment sooner than later. So long as my PSA continues to show zero, I see no reason to do SRT since my margins were all clear.

Posts.Title: Long term side effects?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by creekrat Update on this; Urologist suggested a visit first to the gastro doc. He completed a colonoscopy nine months ago in November and after my visit today, his opinion is " radiation proctolisys " ( sp ). This is damage from the EBRT regimen completed fifteen months ago and it can be clearly seen. No huge surprise! Unrealistic to think there would be no effects. The flatulence and intestinal noises he believes are a separate issue connected to lactose intolerance. Going to try a life without dairy for two weeks to test. Radiation therapy. People who have had radiation therapy that targets the pelvic area also may develop proctitis. Examples of those at risk are people with rectal, ovarian, or prostate cancer who have received radiation treatment directed to those areas. Symptoms of radiation proctitis, most commonly rectal bleeding, will typically occur within 6 weeks after beginning radiation therapy or more than 9 months after its completion. from the Cleveland Clinic

Posts.Title: Big day tomorrow

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by SeaCock Thanks newporter... Here is my uneducated thoughts; I feel that if testosterone causes PC to get worse...wouldn't PC be a young mans disease. The older we get the lower our test gets, the more likely you are to get PC. So I think a case could be made that lower...or dropping test causes PC to kick off and start being an issue. It just seems like if it is truce test causes cancer to grow and be more active...young men should be more prone to cancer than older men... I used to think that too. Even looked at Dr. John Lee and his publications. But common sense has to prevail at some point as well, and more importantly listening to your doctors. There are some studies being conducted but nothing yet in terms of changing medical opinions or protocols.

Posts.Title: colostomy & prostate cancer

Posts.Content: Body pH and oxygen levels can also be factors. The theory being that if we have a lower pH, less than 7.4, it is a more friendly environment for diseases like cancers. With a normal pH comes higher oxygen levels which also helps. One can easily find on the internet the list of foods with higher alkaline content, basically cruciferous and green veggies. All bottled waters are not created equal, some much more acidic (certainly not neutral) than one would think. I now drink nothing but higher alkaline bottled water.

Posts.Title: Acupunture

Posts.Content: Hi Kamie, I tried an all of the above approach including dieting and touted anecdotal supplements when recently diagnosed. My PSA went up still. When I was referred to the number one cancer center in the country, MDA, they tested my PSA to gauge the doubling rate. As said previously, the horse has left the barn. The harm in waiting is that many lymph nodes may need to be taken out as was in my case. It is fortunate that it is very early for your husband. That means there is a strong chance no lymph nodes are taken out. And much better and quicker recovery options. Best wishes.

Posts.Title: My husband was just diagnosed

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ddayglo My surgeon does six weeks it as part of his standard process... - if PSA is Zero at six weeks then it's good news and he likes the idea of sharing that news... if not, then he has the extra data point for the three-month draw. I know I really liked the idea of knowing my PSA after six weeks was zero... it really reduced my stress and made the wait to the three-month PSA a lot easier. For that reason alone I would recommend that everyone ask for a six-week PSA test. Same here. As stated before, it depends on your case. Mine was every six weeks, but now "stretched out" to every 2 months.

Posts.Title: PSA Checked!?!?!?!

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DrKaramanian Disclaimer: This is general medical information and does not establish a physician-patient relationship. There are different types of spreading, local extracapsular extension, seminal vesicle invasion, lymph node involvement, and distant metastasis. A 3T multiparametric MRI is a good test for evaluating extracapsular extension: direct outgrowth of a tumor in the prostate through and beyond the capsule. Surgery is the gold standard because they can cut up the tissue and look at it under a microscope. The MRI is also good at looking for seminal vesicle invasion, although not quite as good. Not ejaculating for 3 days prior to the MRI helps the seminal vesicles fill with fluid and makes tumor invasion easier to identify. Lymph node involvement is possible to be seen, but if it is microscopic, will generally not be seen with MRI. A surgical lymph node dissection can pick up microscopic disease in the prostate, but again, this is because the pathologist can look at it under a microscope. Distant metastasis (e.g., metastasis to the spine) obviously won't be seen on a prostate MRI. I hope this helps clarify the role of MRI. Best regards, Ara Karamanian, MD If after surgery all margins are negative, but SVI, VDI, PNI, and LVI show positive after examination of pathology, does an MRI even help post RALP?

Looks like I'm not the only one with the urine issue during the fun times. I sure hope it goes away sooner than later. It sure blows. One doctor recommended a condom and some lube in the interim. Not a big fan of using a helmet with my lifelong partner.

Posts.Content: Good question, Pratoman. I've been wondering myself why they all of a sudden are testing me with the ultra test. The last score was 0.010. Before they were testing me with the regular PSA and I was less than 0.1 . So I still don't have a valid explanation of why the ultra sensitive test now. Your post maybe clarifies this for me in that they are looking for the next threshold, if it ever happens. I am not sure I would act on a score of something close to 0.05. I remember reading somewhere there is fluctuation from day in these scores. One does not see this if the test is simply resulting in less than 0.1 . But if an ultra test, it does tend to add to the stress level it the result begins to inch up a bit, or fluctuate a bit.

Posts.Title: Some questions about PSA

Posts.Content: Thanks for sharing. I brought Provenge up to my doctors at MDAnderson. They say they won't use it unless the cancer is metastatic, and usually in clinical trials. One doctor did cite its cost with respect to other treatments. This is likely an insurance driven answer as well. Most insurances will simply not cover it. It's about $600,000 or so according to one doctor at MDA. For us patients, if this does indeed work, and it appears to, why wait until the cancer is in advanced stages? The answers are not forthcoming yet from the medical community.

Posts.Title: Provenge and Dendreon and a tour of the manufacturing facility

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by OldTiredSailor Here is a copy of a post I made in another thread - it might explain why the interest in Ultrasensitive PSA tests. The 3-month Ultrasensitive number appears to provide a lot of prognostic information about Biochemical Recurrence: Walsh book (4th edition) page 326 "ULTRASENSITIVE PSA TESTS" references a study done by a Walsh colleague at Hopkins, Dr. Lori Sokoll (professor of pathology and assistant director of clinical chemistry): 750 men 3-months post RP with PSA <0.1 were given ULTRASENSITIVE PSA tests and then monitored for 10-years. 14% of men with ULTRASENSITIVE PSA < 0.03 had an elevated PSA at the end of 10-years 78% of men with ULTRASENSITIVE PSA > 0.03 had an elevated PSA at the end of 10-years There was no report about the clinical symptoms or actual PSA level at 10-years I found a source document for Dr. Sokoll (Journal of Urology Feb 2016), which discusses the same topic but has a little different conclusion than found in the Walsh book. I am not sure if this is the research Walsh was describing but pub date and number of subjects is very similar to what is in the book. Biochemical recurrence-free rates 11 years after surgery were 86.1% (95% CI 83.2–89.0) for prostate specific antigen less than 0.01 ng/ml and 48.9% (95% CI 37.5–60.3) for prostate specific antigen 0.01 ng/ml or greater (p <0.0001). That says to me: An Ultrasensitive PSA < 0.01 had an 86% chance of no biochemical recurrence compared to only about 50% chance of no recurrence if the Ultrasensitive PSA =>.01. My 6-week test is October 9 and 3-months is just after Thanksgiving so I am particularly interested in this topic! Thanks for the info ... very useful.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by HighlanderCFH The urine problem hits about 50% of patients (from what I remember reading) and almost always goes away in the months to come. You'll probably be just fine. With me, Viagra costs $43 a pill. So I could only afford to buy one single pill -- and it's still sitting there because I want to save it for a "meaningful" occasion, like when the gf is visiting. But I don't even know if Viagra will work for me & I'm eager to give it a try. If anyone has any info on these Canadian pharmacies -- a place that is safe to deal with -- that would be very helpful. Looks like I'm not the only one with the urine issue during the fun times. I sure hope it goes away sooner than later. It sure blows. One doctor recommended a condom and some lube in the interim. Not a big fan of using a helmet with my lifelong partner.

Posts.Title: Tomorrow's the big day

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by HighlanderCFH I agree with all of you guys because of the certainty of the case after the removed prostate is examined. Probably, at some point in the future, there will be a StarTrekian type of scan that can show, with virtually no doubt, if there are any other tumors in a prostate aside from what was detected by biopsy. If/when this happens, AS will be less of a risk and the same might be said for focal treatment types. But, until that day arrives, surgery remains the gold standard for cure -- and the primary treatment type with the most post-treatment options, best information on the true status of the case, etc. Gold standard indeed!

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by rooster22 Is there a type of radiation that only penetrates a prescribed distance into tissue? Have heard about it, but want to learn more. Thanx. You might be referencing Proton. That's not typically used post RP, but rather as a primary treatment option. As stated from members, SRT or adjuvant RT with the Variant is state of the art and has shown very successful results. I am a month post SRT. No side effect so far other than slower growing hair in that region, which I am told would rectify itself in the coming months.

Posts.Title: Getting Ready for Post Prostatectomy Radiation

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by function2 If this is posted somewhere as a thread, just point me there, and thanks. I'm 57, I have PSA 7.1 and a Gleason of 8. I'm quite healthy and fit in every other way. My most aggressive tumor is pushing out towards one of the nerve bundles. My consultation today was a recommendation for robotic abdominal surgery, which I probably will do. I opted out of radiation because (1) you have no recourse if you're in the 20% and get the cancer again and (2) bad effects increase over time (more or less). He said if I were 80, radiation might make more sense. My doctor seemed to paint a rosier picture than most recovery descriptions I read online. What are men's real life experiences? He says one night in the hospital (not 2), catheter for one week (not 2-4), back at work in two weeks (I have a desk job), and urinary control most likely after a month. Sexual function may take a while or be compromised forever, I understand that. What say you? Originally Posted by ddayglo Find a good, experienced surgeon and schedule the surgery for the earliest possible time after your biopsy (5-6 weeks). THEN if you have second thoughts about radiation, you can research it knowing that your surgery appointment is already "reserved" and you are already scheduled for the earliest possible time and will never second-guess yourself about waiting. But if you decide to switch to radiation, you can simply cancel the surgery. Going back to work two weeks after the surgery is optimistic... I went back to work 3 1/2 weeks after my surgery, have a desk job, and the first week was rough. Read the DaVinci sticky for many first-person details on others who have had robotic surgery. Good Luck! Agreed... Two weeks is rough. Four is more like it. The better shape you're in, the easier it'll be in the recovery.

Posts.Title: Age 65 with Gleason 9 Treatment Options

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Cubsfan I'm being treated at Loyola Hospital in Chicago, a teaching hospital with a good reputation in regards to cancer. I've met with both the surgical oncologist and the radiation guy. The surgeon uses robotics and has done over 1000 procedures. The RO advises high-energy brachytherapy, then 5 weeks of external beam radiation, with ADT for a total of 1 yr combined pre & post radiation. There is some comfort in the surgical option in that I will know that the bulk (hopefully all) of the PCa is out. The surgeon expects to take out approx. 20 lymph nodes, fingers crossed that they're clean. Both presented good cases, and I'm honestly confused. I'm not comfortable with some of the surgical risks and, of course, some of the possible post-surgery issues. I'm definitely not comfortable with a year of ADT and some of the radiation side-effects don't sound all that great either. My age - 66 in December, and my Gleason score - 8, are factors to consider as well. So, fellow club members, please share your thoughts. Sorry to hear on the diagnosis. Sound like you've done some decent due diligence. Based on the data you've shared, a doctor with over 1000 surgeries and counting may be a good option. In my case they removed 37 lymph nodes, all of which turned out negative. The consensus approach i gathered in my case is a a combination of surgery and radiation, the latter to get the microscopic laggards. And so it worked out so far for me. I am assuming they are recommending the ADT due to the Gleason. The physical shape you're in will be a factor; the better shape you are in, the easier the recovery, not that's it's easy, because it is not. If you're still on the fence, get a second opinion. Try to get the best hands, even if it means traveling out of your area, although Chicago should be properly equipped with great surgeons. Best wishes.

Posts.Title: Tough Decision - I'd like to hear your thoughts

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Cubsfan I'm being treated at Loyola Hospital in Chicago, a teaching hospital with a good reputation in regards to cancer. I've met with both the surgical oncologist and the radiation guy. The surgeon uses robotics and has done over 1000 procedures. The RO advises high-energy brachytherapy, then 5 weeks of external beam radiation, with ADT for a total of 1 yr combined pre & post radiation. There is some comfort in the surgical option in that I will know that the bulk (hopefully all) of the PCa is out. The surgeon expects to take out approx. 20 lymph nodes, fingers crossed that they're clean. Both presented good cases, and I'm honestly confused. I'm not comfortable with some of the surgical risks and, of course, some of the possible post-surgery issues. I'm definitely not comfortable with a year of ADT and some of the radiation side-effects don't sound all that great either. My age - 66 in December, and my Gleason score - 8, are factors to consider as well. So, fellow club members, please share your thoughts. Sorry to hear on the diagnosis. Sound like you've done some decent due diligence. Based on the data you've shared, a doctor with over 1000 surgeries and counting may be a good option. In my case they removed 37 lymph nodes, all of which turned out negative. The consensus approach i gathered in my case is a a combination of surgery and radiation, the latter to get the microscopic laggards. And so it worked out so far for me. I am assuming they are recommending the ADT due to the Gleason. The physical shape you're in will be a factor; the better shape you are in, the easier the recovery, not that's it's easy, because it is not. If you're still on the fence, get a second opinion. Try to get the best hands, even if it means traveling out of your area, although Chicago should be properly equipped with great surgeons. Best wishes.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic I was given an "invisible" service code by a rep at GenomeDx to have my doc use, and that BCBS should pay for it. I have an email from the testing company stating what my max out of pocket cost will be (small amount) should insurance not cover it. The whole thing is the typical negotiation/insurance racket I plan on having the test done. In any case not all states are identical. There is a statement at the BCBS NC site that they do not cover genetic testing for the prostate. But perhaps they are changing policy starting with Decipher, to match Medicare. We'll see. Thanks for the info, Frenchy. Did you have Decipher on your biopsy tissue or post-surgery? May I ask what the results were? Djin Post surgery... it was dead on accurate, btw, for me. High risk... Hence my SRT 9 months post surgery. I have been a member of the zero club since.

Posts.Title: New Guy with salvage radiation questions

Posts.Content: I am on my third week post DaVinci and am walking 2 to 3 miles daily now. I am working somewhat too. I am fortunate in that my employment involves managing a territory. That means lots of emails and phone calls from my home office. Lots of travel too, but I am holding off on that right now. I did about 150 miles of cycling and walking and some exercises in preparation. Getting in shape does indeed help (it helps anyway). Every case is different. Listen to your body. It'll let you know.

Posts.Title: Back to work

Posts.Content: It depends... every case is different. My doctor said two weeks, but that's after I had asked him three weeks after the surgery. How much work was done, the success of the surgery, the skill of the surgeon, and the physical shape you are in are all determining factors. As you're only nine days out post op, it's a bit premature IMHO. I find it interesting, BTW, how certain doctors prescribe Cialis/Viagra while others don't. The ones at MDA indicated that their studies show no dicernable advantage, so they don't prescribe it. So none prescribed in my case. None needed either, BTW. Although they did indicate the need to "exercise" it to prevent shrinkage; at least that's the way they put it.

Posts.Title: I Need a Good Surgeon in Illinois

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Mike A Had Da Vinci on 17 April - almost 4 weeks ago. For month prior to surgery, I quit smoking (after 50 years) and walked 4-5 miles a day, building up to about 3.6 MPH. Got myself in pretty decent shape and I think it has paid off. Since surgery, I have begun walking again. Gradually building up to about 3-4 miles per day in the last week, but keeping pace at around 3.3 MPH. I feel I am getting some decent exercise, but not pushing it to point of any pain or tiredness. A day or so ago, at the end, I felt a little pull developing on right side of groin, so took yesterday off. Woke up today without the pull and did my normal 3 and a half mile walk. All this to ask how much is too much? Is 3-4 miles of walking a day too much after 4 weeks? Is the pace I'm walking too fast? Being a competitive person all my life, I have a tendency to push myself, but certainly don't want to do anything that may jeopardize recover. Will appreciate any advice. Mike Congrats... I worked my way back up from 2 blocks to over 5 miles a day. It was not easy in the beginning. At the 5 miles mark, it was time to get back on the bike. I worked my way from barely being able to do 10 miles to now capably handling longer outings such a 20 and 30 milers with no problems. Bottom line.. listen to your body and adjust accordingly. We're all in various states of fitness and recovery.

Posts.Title: Walking/Exercise Post Surgery

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Mike A Had Da Vinci on 17 April - almost 4 weeks ago. For month prior to surgery, I quit smoking (after 50 years) and walked 4-5 miles a day, building up to about 3.6 MPH. Got myself in pretty decent shape and I think it has paid off. Since surgery, I have begun walking again. Gradually building up to about 3-4 miles per day in the last week, but keeping pace at around 3.3 MPH. I feel I am getting some decent exercise, but not pushing it to point of any pain or tiredness. A day or so ago, at the end, I felt a little pull developing on right side of groin, so took yesterday off. Woke up today without the pull and did my normal 3 and a half mile walk. All this to ask how much is too much? Is 3-4 miles of walking a day too much after 4 weeks? Is the pace I'm walking too fast? Being a competitive person all my life, I have a tendency to push myself, but certainly don't want to do anything that may jeopardize recover. Will appreciate any advice. Mike Congrats... I worked my way back up from 2 blocks to over 5 miles a day. It was not easy in the beginning. At the 5 miles mark, it was time to get back on the bike. I worked my way from barely being able to do 10 miles to now capably handling longer outings such a 20 and 30 milers with no problems. Bottom line.. listen to your body and adjust accordingly. We're all in various states of fitness and recovery.

Posts.Title: Major Milestone

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Michael F Definitely ask your Uro MD for clearance before starting back! I started back with light exercise, no impact, in the gym about 4 weeks post op. Stationary recumbent bike riding, stair master, light free weights. Then graduated to calisthenics: Push ups, pull ups, dips, lunges, sit ups (with no twisting). Everything progressed quickly until..... I noticed a swollen lymph node in my inguinal area and later (5 - 6 months later) developed a strong discomfort in the same area that would flare up several times/ day when walking - especially uphill! I would have to stop for about 15 seconds to let it subside and then continue until the next flare. At my 6 month check up, the MD was not at all concerned about the lymph node or the "inguinal discomfort." He checked me for a hernia. Both conditions eventually vanished. My suggestion is to start back slowly, easily and gradually! Start with low impact cardio workouts to regain your stamina and endurance. I'd avoid strenuous power lifting for at least 6 months and only then work back into it lightly and gradually. Definitely avoid or minimize actions that involve your lower abdominal region - especially twisting motions. Go easy and good luck! Good advice.... I just got the clearance myself on the weights. I have been walking 5 miles every outing for a while now.

Posts.Title: Rising PSA 7 months post prostatectomy

Posts.Content: One of the lucky one percenters to be diagnosed early. Just turned fifty. No symptoms. Just did the required tests, Colonoscopy (they removed 9 polyps (good decision this was)), and biopsy as a result of the elevated PSA, 21.7; 7 out of 12 cores, Gleason 7, one 3+4, and another 4+3, the rest not as high, all on the left side, prostate normal size at 25cc. Many thanks for all whom have posted heretofore. I have been a voracious reader, including The Book, so much so my Uro felt a bit challenged. She's all good. I have been referred to MD Anderson's very own department head, Dr. Davis, whom I hear is one of the great ones. Still assessing treatment plan; RALP, IMRT, Proton. I understand the team at MD Anderson has a committee approach. Right now I am teetering between Proton and RALP. Not much in the forum here on Proton, I noticed (not even a sticky). And not much also in the way of diets, certain foods, supplements, and alkalinities of the body. I think an all of the above approach can't be too faulty. My greatest challenge is my professional schedule; too much traveling all over South Texas. I am wondering if it's worth factoring my professional demands in leaning to Proton. This therapy seems to be the one with the least discomfort, maybe, and the least after-problems and most schedule flexible (no need to take much time off of work). I need to ferret out more data on reoccurrences after Proton therapy, if there is much there to be found. As most that came before me, I am concerned on the potential after-problems if the skilled hands of Dr. Davis fail him. So it's real good to hear/read of the success stories. Also, as I've never had a cavity in my teeth, I am concerned that these therapies will weaken my dental health somehow, not that it's of paramount concern right at the moment. Anyway, a heartfelt MERCI to all of the contributors.

Posts.Title: Five years in the zero club

Posts.Content: I debated posting in my original thread. But it may merit its own. So, when is the best time to really push it, exercise wise? Many have reported that the better shape you're in, the more likely the easier the recovery. I think this is generally true. However one may have to factor in the stage and severity of the PC in our recovery timelines. In my case, I am an avid cyclist. I prepared pre-RP. I had heard and read to wait about five months before hoping on two wheels. And I did. I had been doing pretty decently long walks, about five miles at a clip. But it simply isn't enough to get back into a shape with much less gut. I began cycling over the weekend and have successfully done a decent 20 miler, and a short 10 miler the day before. Some discomfort toward the end, but nothing insurmountable in terms of overdoing it. Alas the muscles near the crease of the abdomen and the leg on my left side exhibit some significant weakness with respect to the right. I can only surmise it to be from the surgery as it was not present pre-RP. A quick check with my surgeon and primary care revealed nada. Still, something was disturbed. I guess I will need to have a bit more patience in letting the muscles regain more strength. Anyone remember anything similar to report in your recovery?

Posts.Title: Surgery this week

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Michael F Hi IS! Not sure why your updated "Signature" has not automatically updated across all of your posts?!?! Your Path Report places you an elevated intermediate risk status based on findings of: - Gleason (4+3) with 80% Pattern 4 - Tertiary Pattern 5 - Seminal Vesicle Involvement - PNI = "extensive" You can go to the GenomeDX website in plug in your post RP Path Report data and then receive a response http://deciphertest.com/patients/is-...-right-for-me/ I would schedule an appointment with the URO Surgeon to review his/her intraoperative surgical findings & the Path Report findings. Have the MD determine your risk for recurrence. Then ask "What additional beneficial info or value can/will 'Decipher' provide?' Most importantly you will need to monitor your PSA at regular intervals. Since your risk status is elevated, discuss with your URO Surgeon the need to monitor with an Ultrasensitive PSA (uPSAMethodology. This can detect a clinically significant rising PSA early. In order to compare results, you must have the uPSA analyzed at The Same Lab using The Same uPSA Methodology each time. Please keep The Forum educated by providing your URO Surgeon's suggestions. Good luck! MF There is a good YouTube video here explaining this also I had the Decipher done. My insurance did pay for it. It is a very useful but also expensive test. It is IMHO worth it. Sounds like your URO is on board with it, likely sage advice.

Posts.Title: I see the newest US News Hospital Rankings are out.....

Posts.Content: One of the lucky one percenters to be diagnosed early. Just turned fifty. No symptoms. Just did the required tests, Colonoscopy (they removed 9 polyps (good decision this was)), and biopsy as a result of the elevated PSA, 21.7; 7 out of 12 cores, Gleason 7, one 3+4, and another 4+3, the rest not as high, all on the left side, prostate normal size at 25cc. Many thanks for all whom have posted heretofore. I have been a voracious reader, including The Book, so much so my Uro felt a bit challenged. She's all good. I have been referred to MD Anderson's very own department head, Dr. Davis, whom I hear is one of the great ones. Still assessing treatment plan; RALP, IMRT, Proton. I understand the team at MD Anderson has a committee approach. Right now I am teetering between Proton and RALP. Not much in the forum here on Proton, I noticed (not even a sticky). And not much also in the way of diets, certain foods, supplements, and alkalinities of the body. I think an all of the above approach can't be too faulty. My greatest challenge is my professional schedule; too much traveling all over South Texas. I am wondering if it's worth factoring my professional demands in leaning to Proton. This therapy seems to be the one with the least discomfort, maybe, and the least after-problems and most schedule flexible (no need to take much time off of work). I need to ferret out more data on reoccurrences after Proton therapy, if there is much there to be found. As most that came before me, I am concerned on the potential after-problems if the skilled hands of Dr. Davis fail him. So it's real good to hear/read of the success stories. Also, as I've never had a cavity in my teeth, I am concerned that these therapies will weaken my dental health somehow, not that it's of paramount concern right at the moment. Anyway, a heartfelt MERCI to all of the contributors.

This therapy seems to be the one with the least discomfort, maybe, and the least after-problems and most schedule flexible (no need to take much time off of work). I need to ferret out more data on reoccurrences after Proton therapy, if there is much there to be found. As most that came before me, I am concerned on the potential after-problems if the skilled hands of Dr. Davis fail him. So it's real good to hear/read of the success stories. Also, as I've never had a cavity in my teeth, I am concerned that these therapies will weaken my dental health somehow, not that it's of paramount concern right at the moment. Anyway, a heartfelt MERCI to all of the contributors.

Posts.Title: My wife is concerned because my PSA is slowly rising every 3 months

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Jim215 Are you reading the decimal placement correctly? At a PSA of 0.1 post-surgery, many ROs would be prepping a patient for salvage radiation. Assuming the most recent PSA result was not an error, another PSA of 0.1 or higher is currently considered to be a biochemical recurrence. As soon as I hit 0.11, I scheduled 40 sessions of SR after monitoring a clear-cut upward trend. This is exactly the reason why a single decimal point while monitoring PSA makes no sense IMHO because it lulls the patient into thinking <0.1 is just fine when, if fact, it could be climbing every 3 months (0.02, 0.04, 0.06, 0.07) and the patient remains totally in the dark. In this case, a second PSA reading of 0.1 or higher is very likely time for action. Chuck, Pratoman, Michael F, MichiganMan16, am I missing something here? That was my very question at MDA. The consensus there is that in terms of results after the PSA begins to rise, the success rate of SRT is no different if the PSA trends from 0.02, 0.05, 0.08 using the ultra test, to <0.1, 0.1, 0.2 for the regular PSA test. It's the very challenge of balancing recovery from surgery with either adjuvant or salvage treatment. Each case is different, obviously. Nonetheless, their research and data from all treated patients suggest the regular PSA test is sufficient.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Michael F Hi Chi !!! Sorry that the "bafflement" continues. Everything that you have posted to date is not suggestive of PC. (Correction:Jim215 has since reminded me that you do in fact have prior biopsies with G6). However, your steadily rising PSA requires continued attention. You now have 3 consecutive PSA rises > 10 since last August. This is 1 metric that must be weighed to make the decision to continue AS. Is it possible that you are experiencing some type of as symptomatic BPH? This would contribute to your rising PSA. Simultaneously this would decrease your PSAD. Just food for thought! What measurement do you use for your prostate size? - TRUS measurement? If so, which date? - MRI measurement? What was the date? Lastly, since you are in/near CHI, have you considered getting a 2nd opinion? I'm not in any way challenging your current URO's position but another opinion provides a fresh perspective and may or may not shed light. Possibly they recommend a different type of imaging scan. Both michiganman16 & ReadyTo Fight went to UC for 2nd opinions and never looked back. For certain you & your MD(s) are monitoring this closely. Good job! Hoping the mystery is soon solved with a benign explanation! MF 20% jump in three months warrants a more aggressive investigation, for sure. It sure would not hurt to get a different set of eyes.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Jim215 Are you reading the decimal placement correctly? At a PSA of 0.1 post-surgery, many ROs would be prepping a patient for salvage radiation. Assuming the most recent PSA result was not an error, another PSA of 0.1 or higher is currently considered to be a biochemical recurrence. As soon as I hit 0.11, I scheduled 40 sessions of SR after monitoring a clear-cut upward trend. This is exactly the reason why a single decimal point while monitoring PSA makes no sense IMHO because it lulls the patient into thinking <0.1 is just fine when, if fact, it could be climbing every 3 months (0.02, 0.04, 0.06, 0.07) and the patient remains totally in the dark. In this case, a second PSA reading of 0.1 or higher is very likely time for action. Chuck, Pratoman, Michael F, MichiganMan16, am I missing something here? That was my very question at MDA. The consensus there is that in terms of results after the PSA begins to rise, the success rate of SRT is no different if the PSA trends from 0.02, 0.05, 0.08 using the ultra test, to <0.1, 0.1, 0.2 for the regular PSA test. It's the very challenge of balancing recovery from surgery with either adjuvant or salvage treatment. Each case is different, obviously. Nonetheless, their research and data from all treated patients suggest the regular PSA test is sufficient.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Michael F Hi Chi !!! Sorry that the "bafflement" continues. Everything that you have posted to date is not suggestive of PC. (Correction:Jim215 has since reminded me that you do in fact have prior biopsies with G6). However, your steadily rising PSA requires continued attention. You now have 3 consecutive PSA rises > 10 since last August. This is 1 metric that must be weighed to make the decision to continue AS. Is it possible that you are experiencing some type of as symptomatic BPH? This would contribute to your rising PSA. Simultaneously this would decrease your PSAD. Just food for thought! What measurement do you use for your prostate size? - TRUS measurement? If so, which date? - MRI measurement? What was the date? Lastly, since you are in/near CHI, have you considered getting a 2nd opinion? I'm not in any way challenging your current URO's position but another opinion provides a fresh perspective and may or may not shed light. Possibly they recommend a different type of imaging scan. Both michiganman16 & ReadyTo Fight went to UC for 2nd opinions and never looked back. For certain you & your MD(s) are monitoring this closely. Good job! Hoping the mystery is soon solved with a benign explanation! MF 20% jump in three months warrants a more aggressive investigation, for sure. It sure would not hurt to get a different set of eyes.

Posts.Title: Latest PSA up

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by GeorgeS As the others have mentioned, being diagnosed with Stage4 prostate cancer with lots of Gleason 8-10 and very high to astronomical PSA might not be as horrid as it obviously sounds. The guys with S4 and lots of metastatic tumors are in many places are now getting ADT+Chemo as the 1st line of treatment. In some areas guys with low volume metastatic PC might get radiation treatments along with ADT or in other areas they may get ADT/CAB/TAB (sorry I can spell out what the letters stand for). There are a few DR's who make use of C11-PET scans and play "wack-a-mole" with radiation therapy and have some success (DR Kwon @ the Mayo Clinic comes to mind). Dr. "Snuffy" Meyers has had success prescribing a few drugs "off label" in the fight against PC with much success. While every case is different and some men's PC responds better than others (or not at all) to treatment there are cases where Stage4 PC can be managed like a "chronic illness" for longer than what might of been possible even just 10yrs ago. I was just reflecting that it was nearly 2yrs ago today that I was diagnosed with Stage4 Metastatic Prostate Cancer. I'm still around. g. You are an inspiration to us all.

Posts.Title: Post Prostatectomy, what is the general consensus on testosterone treatment?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by dml I was on TRT when my PCa was discovered. I had surgery, a favorably pathology (I had a single small focus of Gleason Pattern 4, the rest was 3, clean margins, etc. Six months after my RALP, I resumed TRT and the QOL that goes with it (for me). 15 months later, my PSA remains undetectable. My doc told me that the earlier TRT did not cause my PCa. He also said that if I have a recurrence, it won't be due to the TRT. Trust me, I have read and researched extensively in this area, as have my surgeon and endo. I was the first person either allowed to resume TRT at 6 months post-op. For me, the QOL gained is worth any potential/perceived risks. Please remember that my body is considered to be completely clear of PCa at this point in time. If I have a recurrence, I imagine the TRT will end at that point in time. I will have my 21 month PSA today. Normally, my docs would have switched me to every 6 months by now, but they were a bit more cautious and I've been tested quarterly since my surgery. Everyone needs to decide what risk they think exists. And, what benefit does the TRT bring. Does one outweigh the other? Taking testosterone "just because" makes no sense, IMO. I have a deficiency and it is resolved and I feel so much better with the medication. This study in this link would tend to support your experience, and in fact appears to show a benefit. This interests me only in that there is no true consensus post prostatectomy. The current consensus appears to be a pre-prostatectomy medical opinion applied post prostatectomy.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by jlynn6864 Thanks Chuck - your words are very reassuring! I had no idea he might be in recovery for 4 hours! Dr. Davis told him 2 1/2 hour surgery but didn't mention recovery. Is it typical to be in the recovery room 4 hours? I can't see him during that time? Thank you all for your uplifting thoughts! It's about right... I went in at 9AM, was in the OR 1015'ish, and woke up 4PM'ish in my room. Dr. Davis will likely come out and talk to you during those 4 hours. He came back and talked to me after I had awoken... likely do the same with you. They'll want your husband to do get up later in the evening and take a walk. It's not easy, but an effort must be made. I was a bit dizzy at first as I sat up on the hospital bed. I hung on to the IV carrier as I walked around the nurses station a couple of times. Walking is important to help prevent blood clots, even though compression socks/tubes are worn. The walking also helps with bowel movements and passing gas.

Posts.Signature: PSA 21.9 5 out of 12 cores positive Gleason 7 Diagnosed 6-3-2015 CT and Bone Scan Clear 7-21-15 MDA team meet PSA 26.4 Gleason 7 still but reassessed with two 4+3s instead of just one. Other two at 3+4. 4 out of 12 now deemed positive DaVinci on 8-31-2015 pT3b Prostate and Lymph nodes removed Drain bag removed day three, back home day three Dr. John Davis Saved 75% on the left and 100% on the right 6 weeks post op and three months post op, PSA less than 0.1 Detectable nine months post op at 0.1. Confirmed 6 weeks later with same reading. MRI clear. Began SRT July 11th, 35 sessions to complete on August 26th. Back in the Zero Club post SRT.
Posts.Title: Getting close...getting nervous

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by jlynn6864 Thanks Chuck - your words are very reassuring! I had no idea he might be in recovery for 4 hours! Dr. Davis told him 2 1/2 hour surgery but didn't mention recovery. Is it typical to be in the recovery room 4 hours? I can't see him during that time? Thank you all for your uplifting thoughts! It's about right... I went in at 9AM, was in the OR 1015'ish, and woke up 4PM'ish in my room. Dr. Davis will likely come out and talk to you during those 4 hours. He came back and talked to me after I had awoken... likely do the same with you. They'll want your husband to do get up later in the evening and take a walk. It's not easy, but an effort must be made. I was a bit dizzy at first as I sat up on the hospital bed. I hung on to the IV carrier as I walked around the nurses station a couple of times. Walking is important to help prevent blood clots, even though compression socks/tubes are worn. The walking also helps with bowel movements and passing gas.

Posts.Content: Sorry to hear that, DadOf12. This very question of recurrence concerns me as I continue to ferret out information on which which treatment plan to go with. What I recall reading is what Michael F stated, that there is a 35% rate, but I think it was in reference to surgeries only. I take it to mean that there are microscopic remnants in the surgical solution... and that it's just a matter of time for some. I'll keep you in my prayers, DadOf12.
